awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Remote Health Monitoring from Wearable Antenna Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is significant as the proposed antenna measurement system and deep learning classification algorithms can be integrated with 5G mobile devices and provide real-time, continuous tracking and analysis of a wide range of potential activities. The technology will potentially benefit a diverse population including, but not limited to, tracking elderly people at home or in assisted living facilities, soldiers in the battlefield, and athletes in training or competition. The number of connected wearable devices worldwide is expected to surpass 1.1 billion by the year of 2022 and become a $27 billion market. The proposed approach is adaptive and scalable as more and more wearable devices are being deployed in the era of internet of things (IoT).

This I-Corps project aims to enable dual-use of antennas embedded inside wearable devices for both wireless communication and motion sensing purposes. Recent research findings demonstrate that the input reflection coefficient from an on-body antenna exhibits unique patterns for different motions and can be used for high fidelity human activity classification as an integrated measurement system. It does not require integration of specialized motion sensors into wearable devices, which can reduce the complexity of the system design, the overall power consumption, and the cost. It can monitor both large-scale activities such as walking and small-scale activities such as finger movements, and can operate in both indoor and outdoor environments. The measurement data can be trained and tested by a customized deep convolutional neural network application to provide high-fidelity human activity classification results, realizing the goal of continuously, remote, user-dependent health monitoring.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have achieved the goal of this ICORP project which is to find customer segments and market fit for our motion tracking technology using antennas embedded in the wearable devices. Through the I-Corps workshops, weekly online meetings, and 121 customer discovery interviews, we evolved our business model canvas and established a preliminary assessment of the potential product market fit for our technology. We have successfully identified physical therapists and seniors as the users of our technology.

Two major findings emerged that signaled an immediate need and path forward in the senior health care market space. The first theme was the loss of insight and associated care influence once a senior transitioned from acute care to home care after surgical repair. The second theme was the major changes to Medicare reimbursement codes for Remote Patient Monitoring that became effective in January 2019, and was further clarified in October 2019 to incentivize technology applications in the home. The combination of these items directly connected our wearable motion sensing technology?s potential with the end-users (physical therapists and seniors) and payers (Medicare). The project has resulted in one U.S. patent (US 10,595,742 B2) approved on system and method for classification of body activities with on-body antenna reflection coefficients.

The proposed technology can monitor full-body, compound activities using the waist-worn smart phone antenna; delicate, small-scale finger motions using the wrist-worn smart watch antenna; and head and mouth movement using the Bluetooth earphone antennas. The number of connected wearable devices worldwide is expected to surpass 1.1 billion by the year of 2022 and become a $27 billion market. The proposed approach is adaptive and scalable as more and more wearable devices are being deployed in the era of internet of things (IoT). The project has also provided training opportunities for one minority Ph.D. student who has been dedicated to conducting a thorough market study of the proposed technology, and supporting the transition of the technology when the I-Corps program demonstrates its potential.
